title: [flsaba] Stored XSS in the file and directory name when directories listing

profile.name: Node.js third-party modules
profile.about: This program is used to handle vulnerabilities in the Node.js ecosystem.

vulnerability_information: I would like to report a Stored XSS in module "flsaba". It allows to inject malicious scripts in the file and directory name, store them on the server, then execute these scripts in the browser via the XSS vulnerability. # Module **module name:** https://www.npmjs.com/package/flsaba **version:** 1.1.0 **npm page:** `https://www.npmjs.com/package/flsaba` ## Module Description simple http server with directory listing ## Module Stats [5] weekly downloads # Vulnerability ## Vulnerability Description This XSS vulnerability occurs due to the module represents file and directory name(s) in HTML when creating the listing directory page. The file and directory name(s) are used in the `href` attribute of an anchor element (as well as the value of the anchor itself) without any sanitization. In this way, any malicious script written in the file/directory name and stored on the server, would be executed in the client's browser. ## Steps To Reproduce: - install the `flsaba` module: - `npm install -g flsaba` - in the directory which will be served via `flsaba` (in my case the directory is `~/PoC`), create: - a file with name `">"`: - `touch '">"'` - a directory with name `">"` : - `mkdir '">"'` {F799667} - in the same directory (in my case is `~/PoC`), start `flsaba`: ```shell ~/PoC Â» flsaba flsaba v1.1.0 server listening on port 3000 Directory: /home/ubuntu/PoC ``` {F799666} - visit [http://localhost:3000/](http://localhost:3000/) - the alerts will popup {F799668} {F799669} ## Patch The vulnerability arises in the following lines of code: - [https://github.com/petoem/flsaba/blob/master/server.js#L58](https://github.com/petoem/flsaba/blob/master/server.js#L58) - [https://github.com/petoem/flsaba/blob/master/server.js#L64](https://github.com/petoem/flsaba/blob/master/server.js#L64) ## Supporting Material/References: - OPERATING SYSTEM VERSION: Ubuntu 18.04.4 LTS - NODEJS VERSION: v13.13.0 - NPM VERSION: 6.14.4 - BROWSERS VERSIONS: Firefox Browser 75.0 (64-bit) # Wrap up - I contacted the maintainer to let them know: [N] - I opened an issue in the related repository: [N] Thanks for your time. Best regards, d3lla ## Impact Stored XSS. Any malicious script written in the file/directory name and stored on the server, would be executed in the client's browser, so this vulnerability allows executing malicious JavaScript code in the client's browser.
vulnerability_information_html:
I would like to report a Stored XSS in module "flsaba".
It allows to inject malicious scripts in the file and directory name, store them on the server, then execute these scripts in the browser via the XSS vulnerability.

Module

module name: https://www.npmjs.com/package/flsaba
version: 1.1.0
npm page: https://www.npmjs.com/package/flsaba

Module Description

simple http server with directory listing

Module Stats

[5] weekly downloads

Vulnerability

Vulnerability Description

This XSS vulnerability occurs due to the module represents file and directory name(s) in HTML when creating the listing directory page. The file and directory name(s) are used in the href attribute of an anchor element (as well as the value of the anchor itself) without any sanitization.
In this way, any malicious script written in the file/directory name and stored on the server, would be executed in the client's browser.

Steps To Reproduce:

  • install the flsaba module:
    • npm install -g flsaba
  • in the directory which will be served via flsaba (in my case the directory is ~/PoC), create:
    • a file with name "><img src=x onerror=javascript:alert("xss")>":
      • touch '"><img src=x onerror=javascript:alert("xss")>"'
    • a directory with name "><img src=x onerror=javascript:alert("xss2")>" :
      • mkdir '"><img src=x onerror=javascript:alert("xss2")>"'
  • in the same directory (in my case is ~/PoC), start flsaba: 
~/PoC Â» flsaba                                                                     
flsaba v1.1.0 server listening on port 3000
Directory: /home/ubuntu/PoC

  • visit http://localhost:3000/
  • the alerts will popup

Patch

The vulnerability arises in the following lines of code:

  • https://github.com/petoem/flsaba/blob/master/server.js#L58
  • https://github.com/petoem/flsaba/blob/master/server.js#L64

Supporting Material/References:

  • OPERATING SYSTEM VERSION: Ubuntu 18.04.4 LTS
  • NODEJS VERSION: v13.13.0
  • NPM VERSION: 6.14.4
  • BROWSERS VERSIONS: Firefox Browser 75.0 (64-bit)

Wrap up

  • I contacted the maintainer to let them know: [N]
  • I opened an issue in the related repository: [N]

Thanks for your time.

Best regards,

d3lla

Impact

Stored XSS.
Any malicious script written in the file/directory name and stored on the server, would be executed in the client's browser, so this vulnerability allows executing malicious JavaScript code in the client's browser.

activities.message:
Hi @d3lla,

Thank you for your submission. Your report is currently being reviewed and the HackerOne triage team will get back to you once there is additional information to share.

Kind regards,
@bluetooth_headset

activities.message:
Hi @d3lla, 

Thank you for the report! 

Could you please outline a realistic scenario where the attacker would be able to control the files and directories inside the remote server's directory where this module is running?

I am asking because I don't see any "upload" functionality embedded with this one. Of course, your report is valid and will be triaged, do not worry about this: I am just trying to assess its impact better before doing so! :)

Thanks a lot in advance, and stay safe!

Regards, 
@bluetooth_headset
activities.markdown_message:

I am asking because I don't see any "upload" functionality embedded with this one. Of course, your report is valid and will be triaged, do not worry about this: I am just trying to assess its impact better before doing so! :)

Thanks a lot in advance, and stay safe!

Regards,
@bluetooth_headset

activities.message:
Hi @bluetooth_headset ,
thanks for your prompt reply.
For what I saw, there is no way to upload a file using the functionalities implemented in the module.
I can't find a realistic scenario where an attacker would be able to control the files using only the functionalities provided by this module.

From my experience, a possible realistic scenario could be if this module is used as part of bigger system that implements other functionalities, like as you said, the upload functionality.

Consider the following scenario: a company uses a shared private folder accessible only through its intranet, sharing all the documents related to their business. The folder acts as a sort of knowledge base for the company.
The files are served using the `flsaba` module, so any employee of that company can access the files.
The system allows only employees to upload files (you cannot do other actions) using for example the SFTP protocol. The point is: they have the right permission just to upload files.
If a malicious employee upload a file like one of the above in the PoC, it can execute malicious JavaScript code in the browser of other colleagues that can access that shared folder. 
In this case, the attack is possible due to the XSS vulnerability that affects the `flsaba` module. 

I know that this is a corner case example and require some imagination.
I hope my explanation is clear.

Thanks for your time,
d3lla

activities.message:
Hello @d3lla,

Thank you for your submission! We were able to validate your report, and have submitted it to the appropriate remediation team for review. They will let us know the final ruling on this report, and when/if a fix will be implemented. Please note that the status and severity are subject to change.

Regards,
@bluetooth_headset

activities.message:
Hi everybody,
I hope everyone is staying safe :)

It's more than 2 months already since I reported this vulnerability. Is there any update? 

If the maintainers does not response, how long should we have to wait before disclosing the report?

Should it be 45 days (please, correct me if I am wrong)?

I have a last question. In general, how long does it take for a CVE to be assigned?

Thank you for your patience and have a nice day,
d3lla

activities.message:
@d3lla sorry for the delay. I worked through the whole open low prio reports from the back (you may have already noticed that) and reached out to the maintainer regarding this report a few moments ago.

Some reports may have been untriaged longer than needed as we are a small team of volunteers and we do that in our available free time. I try my best to get as many open reports resolved as possible.

thanks for your reply. I am already aware that you are a small team of volunteers, so please ignore all my other questions where I ask if there is any update (I'm in no hurry).

Thank you very much!
